snippet: Government subsidies for conventional energy still dwarf spending on the fight against climate change. Calls for reforms continue.
abstract: Negotiators at Paris climate talks urge reduction of fossil fuel subsidies; International Money Fund calculates cost at $5.3 trillion annually, including cost of effects on health and environment; global climate agreement aims for mere $100 billion yearly commitment to fund climate change solutions; critics also assert subsidies distort market for clean energy and mainly benefits middle class and rich.
lead_paragraph: Government subsidies for conventional energy still dwarf spending on the fight against climate change. Calls for reforms continue.

headline.main: On Tether to Fossil Fuels, Nations Speak With Money
headline.print_headline: Global Fossil Fuel Subsidies Dwarf Funding Commitment to Climate Change
